abstracts.cdata!:
The overall assessment of the First and
            Second Structural Adjustment Credits (SACs) was
            satisfactory, having achieved its major objectives, with a
            sustainable likelihood. Among the key lessons learned,
            sustaining fiscal reform stands as a major factor in the SAC
            successful operations, for although fiscal reform can be
            hampered by external factors, such as the collapse of the
            Russian economy, with severe fiscal strains for Georgia, the
            country, nonetheless, was able to restore funds. However,
            further gains in resource mobilization should only be
            emphasized once tax compliance is achieved, for as revenue
            mobilization increases, it becomes more difficult to achieve
            incremental tax revenues. The lessons also suggest the
            advantages of a high level counterpart to support successful
            reforms, or resource mobilization. Likewise, certain
            specific measures in the Letter of Development Policy, which
            provided real power and credibility to both institutions,
            were equally advantageous. Credibility of legal status can
            be gradually built, as shown by the instrumental timetable,
            which helped meet prudential targets under the SACs. While
            the transfer of entities to the private sector, may be
            facilitated by vouchers, these may tend to concentrate among
            only a few, whereas a comprehensive listing, could provide
            better results. The benefits of trade liberalization were
            effectively emphasized under both operations.
